citation.article-title: Lactococcus piscium sp. nov. a new Lactococcus species from salmonid fish

p.s: Description of Lactococcus piscium sp. nov.
Lactococcus piscium (L. gen. pl. piscium of fishes)
Cells are short rods to ovoid in shape, mostly in pairs or short chains.
Grows at 5 and 30°C; no growth at 40°C.

Acid is produced from amygdalin, L-arabinose, arbutin, N-acetylglucosamine, cellobiose, D-fructose, galactose, β-gentiobiose, gluconate, glucose, lactose, maltose, D-mannose, mannitol, melibiose, melezitose, D-raffinose, ribose, salicin, sucrose, trehalose, D-turanose and D-xylose.

Acid is not produced from adonitol, D-arabinose, D-arabitol, L-arabitol, dulcitol, erythritol, D-fucose, L-fucose, glycogen, glycerol, inositol, inulin, 2-ketogluconate, 5-ketogluconate, D-lyxose, α-methyl-D-glucoside, α-methyl-D-mannoside, β-methyl-xyloside, rhanmose, L-sorbose, sorbitol, D-tagatose, xylitol and L-xylose.
Starch hydrolysis is slow and wead:.
The long-chain cellular fatty acids are of the straight chain saturated, mono-unsaturated and cyclopropanering types.
The major acids correspond t hexadecanoic acid, Δ11-octadecenoic acid and Δ11-methylenoctadecanoic acid.
The G + C content of DNA is 38.5 mol%, as determined by melting temperature.
The type strain is NCFB 2778 ( = HR1A-68).
